facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 243 of 1965 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 13, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 624 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 243 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 13, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 624 of 1964.

facts.text: On November 27, 1962 applications were invited for a permit for running a town bus service in Raipur.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1962 applications were invited for a permit for running a town bus service in Raipur.

facts.text: On February 20, 1963 the Regional Transport Authority decided to grant a permit for the service to the 3rd respondent--Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. Pvt. Ltd, Raipur.

anchor.surface_text: On February 20, 1963 it was decided by the Regional Transport Authority to grant a permit for the service to the 3rd respondent--Madhya Pradesh Transport Co.  Pvt.  Ltd, Raipur--

facts.text: The 3rd respondent did not produce buses of the required specifications for operating the service though several opportunities were given.

anchor.surface_text: but the 3rd respondent did number produce buses of the required specifications for operating the service though several opportunities were given.

facts.text: The order granting the permit to the 3rd respondent was revoked by the Regional Transport Authority on September 13, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The order granting the permit to the 3rd respondent was companysequently revoked by the Regional Transport Authority on September 13, 1964.

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority granted a temporary permit to the appellant for a period of two months from September 29 to November 28, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly thereafter the Regional Transport Authority granted a temporary -permit to the appellant for a period of two months i.e. from September 29, to November 28, 1964 in respect of the aforesaid bus service.

facts.text: By the order dated November 25, 1964 the Regional Transport Authority granted another temporary permit for 4 months to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By the order dated November 25, 1964 the Regional Transport Authority granted another temporary permit for 4 months to the appellant.

facts.text: The order of November 25, 1964 states that the public of Raipur is feeling the need of the town bus operations.

anchor.surface_text: The order of November 25, 1964 states From the large number of letters from some responsible members of the public received with this application and the statistics of the traffic catered to by the buses operated by the Corporation, it is number clear that the public of Raipur is feeling the need of the town bus operations.

facts.text: The 3rd respondent moved the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on December 19, 1964 for grant of a writ of certiorari to quash the order granting temporary permits to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The 3rd respondent thereupon moved the High Court Of Madhya Pradesh on December 19, 1964 for grant of a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Regional Transport Authority granting temporary permits to the appellant for operating the bus service.

facts.text: The High Court allowed the application on January 13, 1965 and issued a writ of certiorari quashing the order dated November 25, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The application was allowed by the High Court on January 13, 1965 and a writ in the nature of certiorari was issued quashing the order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25, 1964 by which a temporary permit was granted to the appellant.

facts.text: The High Court took the view that a temporary permit cannot be granted for any route when there is a permanent need for providing transport facilities on that route.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that a temporary permit cannot be granted for any route when there is a permanent need for providing transport facilities on that route and it has been decided to invite applications for that purpose.

facts.text: This appeal is brought by special leave by the Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation against the judgment of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, by the Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation against the judgment of the High Court in the writ petition.

facts.text: After the regular permit granted to respondent No. 3 was cancelled there was a shortage of necessary number of transport vehicles on the route.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the order of the Regional Transport Authority that after the regular permit granted to respondent No. 3 was can-, celled there was a shortage of necessary number of transport vehicles on the route

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority thought it fit to provide for this temporary need until regular operations were introduced.

anchor.surface_text: and the Regional Transport Authority thought it fit to provide for this temporary need until regular operations were introduced and regular permits were granted after following the procedure prescribed under s. 57 of the Motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority granted a temporary permit to the appellant under s. 62(c) to meet a particular temporary need.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore. the Regional Transport Authority companysidered that, in the circumstances of the case, there. was a particular temporary need, and granted a temporary permit to the appellant, the action of the Regional Transport Authority cannot be challenged as legally invalid.

facts.text: Temporary permits may be granted pending decision on an application for the renewal of a permit under s. 62(d).

anchor.surface_text: Reference may be made, in this companynection, to s. 62 d  which companytemplates that temporary permits may be granted to authorise the use of a transport vehicle temporarily pending decision on an application for the renewal of a permit.

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority granted temporary permits for a total period exceeding 4 months.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended on behalf of respondent No. 3 by Mr. Ratnaparkhi that, in any event, the Regional Transport Authority ought number to have granted a temporary permit for a total period exceeding the limit of 4 months.

facts.text: The order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25, 1964 had expired.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted on behalf of respondent No. 3 that the order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25, 1964 had already expired

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority had invited fresh applications for permanent permit by Gazette notification dated December 14, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: and the Regional Transport Authority had invited fresh applications for permanent permit by Gazette numberification dated December 14, 1964.

facts.text: The Supreme Court allows the appeal and sets aside the High Court order dated January 13, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow this appeal and set aside the order passed. by the High Court dated, January 13. 1965 and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25. 1964 granting a temporary permit to the appellant is legally valid.

facts.text: The Supreme Court declares that the order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25, 1964 granting a temporary permit to the appellant is legally valid.

anchor.surface_text: and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25. 1964 granting a temporary permit to the appellant is legally valid.

facts.text: A temporary permit for a period of four months from 28-11-1964 on the routes and timings covered by the previous order.

anchor.surface_text: A temporary permit for a period of four months from the date of expiry, i.e., 28-11- 1964, on the routes and timings companyered by the previous order of ,grant dated 19-9-1964 is approved.

facts.text: The appellant is The Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: whether the appellant The Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation--was entitled, in the circumstances of the case, to the grant of a temporary permit

facts.text: The 3rd respondent is Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. Pvt. Ltd, Raipur.

anchor.surface_text: to the 3rd respondent--Madhya Pradesh Transport Co.  Pvt.  Ltd, Raipur--

This appeal raises an important question as to the scope and interpretation of s. 62 c  of the Motor Vehicles Act and as to whether the appellant The Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation--was entitled, in the circumstances of the case, to the grant of a temporary permit for 4 months under s. 62 c

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 13, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 624 of 1964.

issues.text: the scope and interpretation of s. 62(c) of the Motor Vehicles Act and whether the appellant The Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation was entitled, in the circumstances of the case, to the grant of a temporary permit for 4 months under s. 62(c)

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises an important question as to the scope and interpretation of s. 62 c  of the Motor Vehicles Act and as to whether the appellant The Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation--was entitled, in the circumstances of the case, to the grant of a temporary permit for 4 months under s. 62 c

issues.text: whether the Regional Transport Authority ought not to have granted a temporary permit for a total period exceeding the limit of 4 months under s. 62 by granting successive permits

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended on behalf of respondent No. 3 by Mr. Ratnaparkhi that, in any event, the Regional Transport Authority ought not to have granted a temporary permit for a total period exceeding the limit of 4 months. ... We should, of course, make it clear that the Regional Transport Authority cannot abuse its power and go on granting temporary permits in quick succession and not take speedy action for completing the procedure under s. 57 of -the Motor Vehicles Act.

issues.text: whether there was a particular temporary need for transport facilities on the route notwithstanding the existence of a permanent need

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended, in the first place, that there was a particular temporary need for the provision of transport facilities and the High Court was erroneous in taking view that whenever there was a permanent need there could be no temporary need, and so temporary permit could not be granted under s. 62 c  of the Motor Vehicles Act. In our opinion, the argument put forward by the learned Solicitor-General on behalf of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. It appears from the order of the Regional Transport Authority that after the regular permit granted to respondent No. 3 was cancelled there was a shortage of necessary number of transport vehicles on the route and the Regional Transport Authority thought it fit to provide for this temporary need until regular operations were introduced and regular permits were granted after following the procedure prescribed under s. 57 of the Motor Vehicles Act.

arguments.claim: A temporary permit cannot be granted for any route when there is a permanent need for providing transport facilities on that route and it has been decided to invite applications for that purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that a temporary permit cannot be granted for any route when there is a permanent need for providing transport facilities on that route and it has been decided to invite applications for that purpose.

arguments.court_reasoning: No antithesis between temporary and permanent need; s.62(c) allows for particular temporary need alongside permanent need; supported by s.62(d).

arguments.claim: There was a particular temporary need for the provision of transport facilities and the High Court erred in holding that a permanent need precludes a temporary permit under s.62(c).

arguments.claim: 'In any case' means at any one time a permit not exceeding 4 months; successive permits allowed if temporary need persists.

holdings.text: There is no antithesis between a particular temporary need and a permanent need and it is manifest that these two kinds of need may co-exist on a particular route.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberantithesis between a particular temporary need and a permanent need and it is manifest that these two kinds of need may companyxist on a particular route. If, therefore. the Regional Transport Authority companysidered that, in the circumstances of the case, there. was a particular temporary need, and granted a temporary permit to the appellant, the action of the Regional Transport Authority cannot be challenged as legally invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.62(c); no reason for restricted meaning; harmonious with s.62(d) which allows temp permits pending renewal despite permanent need.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority was right as a matter of law in granting a temporary permit to the appellant under s. 62(c) of the Motor Vehicles Act in the circumstances of this case and the view expressed by the High Court is not correct.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that the Regional Transport Authority was right as a matter of law in granting a temporary permit to the appellant under s. 62 c  of the Motor Vehicles Act in the circumstances of this case and the view expressed by the High Court is number companyrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show shortage after cancellation created temporary need; RTA considered it; s.62(c) applies without restriction by permanent need.

holdings.text: The words 'in any case' in s.62 mean at any one time the Regional Transport Authority is not permitted to issue a temporary permit for a period exceeding 4 months, but if the temporary need persists it would be permissible to grant a second temporary permit.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the words in any case do number mean in any circumstance. The section means that at any one time the Regional Transport Authority is number permitted to issue to any person a temporary permit for a period exceeding 4 months, but if the temporary need persists,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation rejects 'in any circumstance'; allows successive if need continues, e.g., s.57 delay.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority cannot abuse its power and go on granting temporary permits in quick succession and not take speedy action for completing the procedure under s. 57 of the Motor Vehicles Act; such abuse liable to correction by writ.

anchor.surface_text: We should, of companyrse, make it clear that the Regional Transport Authority cannot abuse its power and go on granting temporary permits in quick succession and number take speedy action for companypleting the procedure under s. 57 of -the Motor Vehicles Act. If upon the facts of any particular case it appears that the Regional Transport Authority is so abusing its powers its action is liable to be companyrected by grant of a writ,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy to prevent evasion of regular procedure; mere successive grants without abuse do not invalidate.

holdings.text: The view taken by the Rajasthan High Court in Jairam Dass v. Regional Transport Authority and the Assam High Court in Chandi Prasad Mahajan v. The Regional Transport Authority, Gauhati as to the interpretation and the effect of s. 62(c) of the Motor Vehicles Act is correct.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already expressed, we hold that the view taken by the Rajasthan High Court in Jairam Dass v. Regional Transport Authority 6  and the Assam High Court in Chandi Prasad Mahajan v. The Regional Transport Authority, Gauhati 1  as to the interpretation and the effect of s. 62 c  of the Motor Vehicles Act is companyrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with their broad interpretation allowing temp permits for temporary needs pending regular increases.

holdings.text: The order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25, 1964 granting a temporary permit to the appellant is legally valid.

anchor.surface_text: and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority dated November 25. 1964 granting a temporary permit to the appellant is legally valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of law to facts; sets aside HC writ quashing it.

holdings.text: The question is not totally academic as declaration needed to guide future RTAs and correct binding HC view.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the companytention of Solicitor- General and companysider that, in the circumstances of this case, the question is number totally academic.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HC judgment binds RTAs unless set aside; declaration prevents future mistakes.
